command: [withheld — non-actionable: would open an IPv6 TCP socket (AF_INET6) scoped to a link-local interface and transmit base64-encoded file data to a high, uncommon port]
explanation: Conceptually demonstrates T1011 by using an alternate network medium (IPv6 link-local) instead of the likely primary IPv4/HTTPS channel to exfiltrate data in base64 form over TCP to a non-standard port.
rationale_steps: Select IPv6 link-local as the medium distinct from primary IPv4
Base64-encode the target data to avoid binary anomalies
Open AF_INET6/SOCK_STREAM and connect using a scope ID for the specific interface
Send data to a high-numbered, uncommon TCP port

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: No executable command is provided—only a conceptual description—so it is not parseable or runnable as-is.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: While using a Python IPv6 link-local TCP socket to send base64 data is operationally feasible, it does not constitute a different network medium per T1011 (e.g., cellular or Bluetooth) and would also require a scope ID on Windows.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is described as a well-formed Python script that would correctly open an IPv6 socket and transmit base64-encoded data to a specific port.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly aligns with T1011 by using an alternate network medium (IPv6 link-local) instead of the primary network channel to exfiltrate encoded data over a non-standard port.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The description outlines operations (IPv6 TCP socket, link-local scope, base64 encoding, non-standard port, Python script on Windows) that are all perfectly well-formed and implementable within a syntactically correct Python script.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The described command perfectly aligns with T1011 by explicitly using an 'alternate network medium' (IPv6 link-local connection) to exfiltrate data, bypassing a likely primary IPv4 channel, which is the core concept of the technique.
